job_title: Registered Medica Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Love my coworkers!! Amazing patients and doctors!
cons: Not alot of cons. Just management sometimes.

job_title: Nursing in Jackson Heights, NY
pros: Apicha has a wonderful mission of helping vulnerable communities. The people that work for the organization really care about the patients and each other. I could always lean on my coworkers for support. The patients are grateful for the organizations values and diversity inclusion.
cons: The people that work for Apicha are supportive but the management itself lacks appreciation and support for their workers. They expect workers to figure out how to run the clinic by themselves but then blame their workers if their is an issue that arises. Being a new clinic, they lack a lot of policies and are not attentive to the specific needs for the community they serve. Not a competitive work environment for proper compensation and benefits and lack of career growth in any department you are in.

job_title: Patient Associate in Jackson Heights, NY
pros: Good people often work there
cons: There is no respect for employees, little room for growth, and very low pay. Benefits are minimal, and bonuses and raises are rare or non-existent

job_title: Prep Navigator in New York, NY
pros: The location is nice. It's in chinatown.
cons: Management throws newbies in without training them at all and expects us to figure things out without telling us how to do any of the work. Nearly everyone who works there is a new hire because there's such a high turnover rate. Everyone is underpaid. Management often yells at underlings for simple mistakes. Do not expect them to be prepared to show you what to do at all on the first day or even by week two. They will nitpick over small things like email uniformity, style of email communication, and expect 100% compliance, but won't show you how to do your actual job. They waste your time. The office is made up of working class people from various backgrounds, cultures, and identities. Management discriminates against peoples religions and genders not infrequently. Also the pay is very low. I am paid $19 an hour and have coworkers paid $15 and $16 for the same or similar jobs.

job_title: Patient Engagement Specialist in New York, NY
pros: The people you work with are great
cons: Management and pay are complete and total jokes

job_title: Navigator in New York, NY
pros:
Apicha serves a very select but diverse group of people. 
Co workers are some of the best
cons:
No raises nor bonus
no contribution to retirement savings plan
no room for promotion 
low pay 
extremely high turn over rate in very department
Poor communication in management 
repetitive, redundant documentation
Micro management

review_title: A place with potential but awful management
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in New York, NY
pros: Your co workers become family.
cons: Administration does not care about helping employees progress. No bonus or raises are given to any one in a position that's not administrative.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in New York, NY
pros: I am given paid holidays
cons: This is the possibly the worst management in New York

job_title: Patient Associate in New York, NY
pros: Like family. Decent place to work.
cons: Not much but the pay to be honest.

job_title: Project Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: There is good department moral
cons: They may have low balled me.

job_title: Prep Navigator in New York, NY
pros: Good frontline workers who are untrained
cons:
Lack of training
Behind few years of paper documentation
Micro managing
No conversation to improve quality
No protection for workers
I was sexually harassed by patient and my supervisor didn’t protect me nor support me, but hand me more work to do. After I quit this place management was busy blaming me so they don’t have to taking responsibility
Zero respect
Especially management is known for disrespectful.

job_title: Prep Navigator in New York, NY
pros: location, work from home, impactful work
cons: stressful, negative environment, bad pay

job_title: Program Coordinator in New York, NY
pros: Started here right after graduation and honestly, I've learned more than my program could have ever taught me because of the real-world applications.
cons: Grant-funded work isn't the most glamorous.

review_title: Get your experience then get out as fast as you can.
job_title: Patient Associate in New York, NY
pros: Being able to serve the underserved community and being able to provide services to help as best as you can.
cons: Low pay. Terrible Management. No regard towards employees. Staff is not properly trained or educated on the community. No growth within the company. No pay raise; EVER.

review_title: Disorganized, lack of training, rude/disrespectful supervisor!!
job_title: Care Manager in New York, NY
pros: There is no pros, all cons
cons: Not compassionate to workers, most of the supervisors are rude to their workers, if anything the workers make any mistake supervisors literally yells at them infront of everyone! Not compassionate, no student benefit, overwork, very stressful work, no training, you gotta teach everything yourself!

job_title: Medical Case Manager in New York, NY
pros:
• Team player/support from the Medical Case Management/PrEP Staff/Trans Health/Prevention Team
• Great providers, they understand the concerns from the staff and are always supportive.
cons:
• No communication between managers and staff 
• No support from management but will get reprimanded when job is not done right. 
• Management is quick to throw staff under the bus!
• Unfair treatment of staff by managers – felt as if we were treated like children not adults. 
• Turn over rate is only from support service due to horrible management. 
• Lack of personal space – limited space to physically move around from the support service dept. 
• Lack of training and updated information regarding duties that are assigned - you receive a book to learn about HIV and the rest, you figure it out yourself 
• Had no supervision and training regarding said task – felt like task was just assigned and to do it. 
• What is mentioned on the job description is 25% true, the rest is at random and do it now. 
• LGBTQ is growing in the community and staff members DOES NOT get training for pronouns and Trans Health. 
• These training should have been provided the 3 months upon my arrival as a Medical Case Manager, but received none.  Along with my other co-worker in support services.

job_title: Patient Navigator in New York, NY
pros: Everyone great finds something better
cons: The entire department in Health Home

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Once you find your people, it's less overwhelming and frustrating. Certain supervisors are great depending on your department, but Support Services is a bureaucratic and shade-filled nightmare.
cons: Constant screaming and public humiliation is distracting, and makes it hard to focus on deadlines that are already unrealistic due to understaffing. Also, it's embarrassing when all patients are constantly asking about staff turnover and expressing frustration over having to explain their situation repeatedly every time a new person starts. The 8 hour days (minimum) plus only 30 mins lunch actually makes you LESS productive. This is frustrating because you work 9-5:30 or 10:30am-7pm, which prevents you from tending to your own life/health. Everyone is constantly depending on FMLA due to how hard it is to get time off.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Most co-workers are supportive of each other, even across departments. FQHC status earned organization more money for improvements to facility and programming.
cons: Stress and dissent is palpable on non-patient floors. Staff are perpetually undermined and/or openly berated by their respective managers in front of other departments. Being innovative is a farce, and employee initiatives to improve productivity are often looked down upon. Case loads are overwhelming, and when seeking or requesting additional support, staff are denied and berated for not being able to handle work. No room for career growth in the organization; vertical advancement is next to nil, and if offered financial compensation less than meager. Constructive criticism about anything is considered blasphemous.

review_title: Get your experience, and move on to something else.
job_title: Care Manager in Canal Street, NY
pros: Honestly, for me the best part about Apicha was the staff I worked with on the floor. They were very nice, educated, talented people that really cared about the client's they served. I personally believe, that I gained experience from Apicha; they gave me the opportunity to learn and obtain work experience in case management, and that experience allowed me to expand my horizons, and look for employment elsewhere.
cons: There is little/ to no room for growth. Management doesn't listen any of the concerns presented by the staff. The Salaries they have are not competitive. No salary increase.

job_title: Clinician in New York, NY
pros: Staff and patients are nice to work with. One or two mid level managers are very supportive and that goes a long way with staff shortages and lack of communication from upper management. Management should get a zero rating.
cons: Lack of communication and empathy from managers. Upper management runs the clinic remotely, but never seen in clinic or come talk with people doing the real clinical work. They don't give a darn about staff concerns, do no listen to staff for ideas, and do not care how you get the work done, putting patients and staff in danger. One mistake and you are fired. Too many complaints, you are fired. A medical provider (or manager) doesn't like you for whatever reason, you are fired. This results in very high turnover. For 3 year they have fought against joining a union.

review_title: Good first/transitional job but maybe don't pursue your career here.
job_title: Care Manager I in New York, NY
pros: Easy hire process, flexibility, quality experience, great learning opportunity, friendly and supportive co-workers, questions are encouraged, clean workplace, great if you like interacting with people, satisfaction/ability to see impact of your work on those you serve.
cons: Lower average pay than similar positions at other companies, lack of support/transparency from management, lack of well-rounded training experience, Lack of apparent opportunities for upward growth.

job_title: Food and Nutrition Liaison in New York, NY
pros: The job is suitable for crazy people. I consider I am crazy because I have passion for helping people who need help and I don't care about the reward for my work.
cons: The middle and low level managers are too crazy for their poor little authorities, they thought that would be the last valuable assets for them to carry to their coffins.

job_title: Administrative
pros: Co-workers, doctors, helping patients as much as you can...that's about it.
cons: Managers and directors don't manage nor direct staff, degrading & make you are totally incompetent, 8.5 hours a day/5 days a week. Don't even think about getting sick or if have an emergency unless you have an official doctor's note or proof, even during your "break" since you only get 30 minutes, which is illegal but they don't care and instead of doing THEIR job, all they do is watch like hawks for something to yell at you about IN FRONT OF EVERYONE. I've seen staff come & go and the turnover rate is not only incredible but guess what? Their work ends up becoming yours.

review_title: looks great on paper, but rife with bureaucracy and skirts the line of fraudulent activity
job_title: Outreach Worker in New York, NY
pros: looks good on paper, a lot of interaction with patients
cons:
you don't feel like you're actually making a difference
caseload is unreal
most of the upper management is belittling 
unsafe work environments

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
-You get to work alongside some of the most hardworking, genuine people, all of whom care deeply for their clients
-You make many high-quality connections that will take you far
-You learn valuable skills that are transferable
cons:
-You're underpaid, overworked, and micromanaged
-High turnover rate at Apicha because nobody wants to work there long-term
-Supervisors from other programs may ask you to assume more responsibilities than you agreed to in your initial HR paperwork
-Upper management have little to no compassion and will find a way to get you

job_title: Prep Navigator in New York, NY
pros: Great co-workers, we just joined a union, steady hours, options for overtime
cons: Not flexible for doctors appointments or school, mediocre insurance, lots of new hires all of the time, people are in and out of the door

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: As the title says, it looks good on your resume. Some of the people working there are nice also.
cons: Upper management blames staff for everything. If you enjoy feeling overwhelmed, talked down too, and stressed all the time then this is the place for you.

job_title: Client Recruiter in New York, NY
pros: Mission Oriented and innovative dynamic with keen target on at risk communities,
cons: Patronizing leadership but nice people generally, very bad neighborhood to get to from most parts of the city

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Passionate colleagues with a desire to help others. Ability to see how our work improves the life of our patients
cons: Lack of growth opportunities. No salary raises. No tuition remission. Losing your earned vacation if not taken during fiscal year

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY

cons: Horribly aggressive and punitive management, toxic environment, worst pay ever (even for master's level staff), lack of privacy, 10-12 hour work days, some work on weekends, attitude of "you should be lucky to have a job"
